awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for the 25th International Meshing Roundtable
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports student participation in the 25th International Meshing Roundtable conference will be held on September 27-30, 2016 in Washington DC.  Meshing is the decomposition of complex objects into simple parts for design, display, and analysis. As technologies change in computing and computer-aided design and manufacturing the demand for meshing seems only to increase. 

The IMR conference includes four short courses, four invited speakers, and presentations of reviewed papers, research notes, and posters, and a professional development session particularly targeting students and postdocs. This award will support registration and some travel expenses for a dozen students (undergraduate to postdoctoral, coming from U.S. universities, national labs, or non-profit research organizations) to exchange ideas with experts from around the world, fostering collaboration and recognition that can help them launch their careers. (For selection criteria, see the conference web site http://www.imr.sandia.gov/25imr)

por.por_cntn:
The award allowed for a total of 14 graduate students and postdocs from the U.S. to travel to and attend the International Meshing Roundtable conferences. These are the leading meetings for research in the important field of mesh generation. The topics included the following: CAD and computational geometry issues for meshing, mesh generation and modification, meshing for high-performance and distributed computing, and implications of applications for meshing (finite element, finite volume analysis and modeling, geometric modeling, computer graphics and scientific visualization, and others).

The awardees typically write a paper and gives a talk presenting their results. In addition, they attend short course where the lecturers were internationally known experts in mesh generation. The instructors addressed both theoretical and practical problems for the design and implementation of grid generation algorithms and software. The courses were ideal for graduate students that are just entering the field and for advanced graduate and postdoctoral students that want to expand their current skills and knowledge.

The conference also helps students and postdocs interact with other researchers and form new collaborations. During the award period, we introduced a new concept to better allow for this - an Open Spaces session. It was particularly helpful to expand their professional development skills and knowledge in the research community. A number of topics were discussed in an open setting, and both experienced and new people in the community were participating.

The broader impact of the award is in both basic and translational research and education, as well as in the engagement of underrepresented demographic groups. The students were exposed to new ideas, had the opportunity to talk to experts from around the world, to receive feedback and guidance related to their work here in the U.S. The intellectual merit of the project is the combined intellectual merit of participants’ peer-reviewed research contributions that were published in the proceedings and the conference web site.
